MissionCommands.Message: Welcome to the ECS lesson. In this lesson we will learn about the Lunar Modules Environmental Control System (ECS).
Press F4 to switch to the Lunar Module.
As with the Command Module, the Environmental Control System (ECS) provides a habitable environment for two astronauts while the LM is separated from the CSM.
It permits the crew to decompress and repressurize the cabin in accordance with mission requirements, such as when performing EVAs to walk on the Moon.
It also controls the temperature of electronic equipment and provides water for drinking, cooling, fire extinguishing, and food preparation.
The ECS comprises an atmosphere revitalization section (ARS), an oxygen supply and cabin pressure control section (OSC PCS), a water management section (WMS) and a heat transport section (HTS).
It also supplies oxygen and water to the portable life support system (PLSS) used during EVAs.

Let us start with the Atmosphere Revitalization Section, the ARS. This system uses oxygen to pressurize a suit circuit where a recirculation system provides clean and fresh air to the crew, and the cabin.
The ARS provides temperature control, filters CO2 and odors, excessive moisture. It can isolate itself from the cabin, or provide oxygen to the cabin.
Oxygen circulation is maintained by centrifugal fans, and Water separators remove excess moisture after the cooling phase.
Heating and cooling are accomplished by passing the oxygen through heat exchangers where coolant from the Heat Transport Section controls its temperature.

The ECS indicators on panel 2 gives you a good overview of the ARS. The SUIT and CABIN pressure and temperature shows the status of the circuit, and the CO2 indicators shows the current level of CO2 in the system.
In normal operation the SUIT ISOL valve is set to SUIT FLOW and conditioned oxygen flows to the suits and into the suit circuit.
The CABIN position of the SUIT GAS DIVERTER valve is used during pressurized-cabin operation to divert sufficient conditioned oxygen to the cabin to control carbon dioxide and humidity levels.
Pulling the valve handle selects the EGRESS position to isolate the suit circuit from the cabin and is used for all unpressurized cabin operations such as EVA.
With the SUIT GAS DIVERTER valve set to CABIN, cabin discharge oxygen is returned to the suit circuit through the CABIN GAS RETURN valve.
In the AUTO mode, the cabin pressure controls the valve. If the cabin is depressurized, the valve is closed to prevent suit pressure loss or waste air into the cabin.

The air is then filtered through the CO2 filters, before being recirculated by the suit circuit fans. Two fans are available, but only one is used at a time. The fan can be selected on panel 2. Set it to OFF.
The suit circuit is not being recirculated and the differential pressure in the circuit will be low. The FANS comp lt and the master alarm will be triggered after a few seconds. Turn it back to 1.
It is important to monitor the fans during the mission. The ECS: SUIT FAN 1 (panel 11) and the ECS: SUIT FAN 2 (panel 16) powers the fans.
The conditioned oxygen is next routed to two, parallel-redundant water separators through the water separator selector (WATER SEP SEL) valve. This is normally pushed IN to select separator 1.
Only one water separator is operated at a time. It removes moisture from the air and supplies the water to the subliminators in the Heat Transport Section.
The conditioned oxygen from the water separator is mixed with makeup oxygen from the Oxygen Supply System (OSCPCS) to maintain system pressure.
The mixture then flows through the regenerative (heating) heat exchanger, where the temperature may be increased, to the SUIT ISOL valves. This completes a full circuit in the ARS.

The SUIT TEMP valve on the water control module controls the flow of coolant through the regenerative heat exchanger. Setting the valve to INCR HOT increases temperature; setting it to DECR COLD reduces the temperature.
Let's take a look at the Oxygen Supply and Cabin Pressure Control Section (OSCPCS). This system stores gaseous oxygen and maintains cabin and suit pressure by supplying oxygen to the ARS.
It replenishes losses due to crew metabolic consumption and cabin or suit leakage, and is supplied into the ARS circuit based on measured pressure.

There are four oxygen supplies, two in the descent stage and two in the ascent stage. The descent supply is used during unstaged operations and lunar stay, while the ascent supply is used during ascent and rendezvous.
O2 from the two descent tanks flow into a common manifold, before entering the lunar module through the DES O2 valve. The valve must be set to open to allow oxygen to flow into the system.
While one valve controls both DES O2 tanks, the ascent O2 tanks each have their own valve, #1 ASC O2 and #2 ASC O2 valve, both on the oxygen control panel where the DES O2 valve is.
Both the DES O2 and the ASC O2 tanks supplies oxygen into a manifold that supplies O2 to the CABIN REPRESS valve, the demand regulators (REG A and REG B) and the PLSS FILL valve.
The electrical CABIN REPRESS valve can be used to repressurize the cabin during emergencies where cabin pressure is low, or manually. The CABIN REPRESS valve controls this and is usually set to AUTO.
In AUTO, this valve will energize if the cabin pressure goes below 3.7 psia, and de-energize when the cabin pressure goes over 4.4 psia.
The demand regulators is the entrypoint to the ARS suit circuit. They maintain the pressure of the suit circuit at a level consistent with normal requirements.
The two valves are manually controlled and are usually set to the same position. Two exists because of redundancy.
The CABIN position is selected during normal pressurized-cabin operations, to provide oxygen at 4.8±0.2 psia.
Setting the regulators to EGRESS maintains suit circuit pressure at 3.8±0.2 psia.
The DIRECT 02 position provides an unregulated flow of oxygen into the suit circuit and the CLOSE position shuts off all flow through the regulator.

Two cabin relief and vents valves exists, one on each hatch. Setting them to AUTO will let them relieve cabin pressure if it exceeds 5.8 psia. It can also relieve pressure while kept in OPEN and can be used to depressurize the cabin.
Let's depressurize the cabin. First, set the REG A to EGRESS.
Then set the redundant REG B to EGRESS as well. Remember, these valves should be equal.
Then set the SUIT GAS DIVERTER valve to EGRESS (PULL).
Close the overhead hatch.
Then set the forward hatch vent valve to OPEN to let oxygen flow out through the vent. When cabin pressure is 0, close the valve.
If you would be on the surface of the Moon, you could now open the hatch and climb down the ladder to the surface.
To repressurize the cabin again, first set Demand REG A to CABIN.
Then do the same for Demand REG B.
Then push the SUIT GAS DIVERTER to CABIN
Then set the CABIN REPRESS valve to AUTO.
The cabin pressure should now be repressurized. Notice that the suit circuit was pressurized during the entire procedure.
The next system we will look at is the WATER MANAGEMENT SECTION (WMS).
The main function of the Water Management Section is to supply drinking water, and water for food preparation, fire fighting, cooling and to the subliminators.

The WMS allows water to flow from the water separators to the subliminators, and from the water tanks to the subliminators. The subliminators are part of the Heat Transfer Section and will be described later.
Four water tanks are available, two in the descent stage and two in the ascent stage. This is the main supply of water.
Reclaimed water from the Water Separators is used only by the subliminators for evaporative cooling.
When using the Descent Water Supply, the WATER TANK SELECT valve must be set to DES.
The water then flows from the descent tanks, through the selector valve. With the PRI EVAP FLOW #1 valve set to OPEN, water is then routed to the primary subliminator.
The WATER TANK SELECT valve is a dual spool, and water from the Water Separators enter through the secondary spool and joins the water to the primary subliminator.
Setting the WATER TANK SELECT valve to ASC routes water from the ascent tanks, with the PRI EVAP FLOW #1 valve set to OPEN, to the primary subliminator.
The water that flows through the WATER TANK SELECT valve enters a regulator before proceeding towards the subliminator. If this fails, the PRI EVAP FLOW #2 can be used.
Water then flows directly from the ascent water tanks through a secondary pressure regulator, the PRI EVAP FLOW #2 valve to the primary sublimator.

Under emergency conditions (failure of the primary HTS loop), water from the ascent tanks is routed through the secondary manifold (secondary pressure regulator) by setting the SEC EVAP FLOW valve to OPEN.
This allows for flow of water to the second in-series pressure regulator to the secondary subliminator, and a suit circuit sumbliminators used for emergency temperature control in the ARS.
To divert water, the WATER TANK SELECT valve is then set to SEC.
The last section we want to cover is the Heat Transport Section (HTS)
The HTS consists of a primary coolant loop and a secondary coolant loop where a water-glycol solution circulates each loop.

The glycol is used to cool down electrical equipment mounted on cold plates. The coolant carries the heat away from these, cooling them down, to then vent the excess heat through the subliminators into space.
A coolant pump recirculation assembly contains HTS coolant pumps used to circulate the coolant in the loops.
The pumps are started by closing the ECS: GLYCOL PUMP 1 and 2 circuit breakers on panel 11, and setting the GLYCOL selector switch to PUMP 1 or PUMP 2.
Open the ECS: GLYCOL PUMP 1 circuit breaker on panel.
Notice the Master Alarm, and the decrease of the GLYCOL PSIA, and the increasing GLYCOL temperature.
Close the ECS: GLYCOL PUMP 1 circuit breaker on panel and monitor the indicators, the situation should be recovering.

If both pumps fail, you should switch to the secondary coolant loop by setting the WATER TANK SELECT valve to SEC, setting the GLYCOL switch to INST (SEC), and closing the ECS: GLYCOL PUMP SEC circuit breaker.

Part of the coolant leaving the recirculation assembly flows to the suit circuit heat exchanger to cool the suit circuit gas of the ARS. The remainder of the coolant flows to electronic equipment mounted on cold plates.
The coolant then converges and flows to the liquid cooled garment water-glycol heat exchanger (cooling suit water), to the aft equipment bay cold rails.
A portion of the warmer coolant flow returning from aft cold rails can be diverted through the SUIT TEMP valve and into the suit circuit regenerative heat exchanger for temperature control.

The coolant then converges again and enters the primary evaporators. This will cool down the coolant before it passes the ascent and descent batteries, coolant reservoirs, then returns to the recirculation assembly.
The subliminator decreases the temperature of the coolant by rejecting heat to space through the sublimation of water, followed by the venting of the generated steam through an overboard duct.
The secondary (emergency) coolant loop is quite similar and I suggest to check out the ECS chapter in the Reentry Lunar Module Flight Manual for details.
Lastly, I want to mention some of the available checklists. Even if there is a lot to the ECS, it is rather simple to operate.
The checklists can be found in the Mission Pad -> Lunar Module -> ECS section.
As with the other Lunar Module checklists, there is in many cases one checklist for the unstaged configuration and another for the staged configuration.
The nominal unstaged ECS setup can be achieved by running the ECS BASIC (UNSTAGED) checklist. Do this now.
Before staging, usually before the Lunar Ascent, the ECS BASICS (STAGED) checklist should be completed to reconfigure the ECS for a staged setup.
If you are unsure if the ECS is set up correctly, you can run the ECS BASICS checklist.
Periodic monitoring should be done frequently over the Lunar Module parts of a mission, and the repressurization and depressurization checklists can be used for EGRESS configurations.
And that's it for now, good job on completing this lesson. I recommend you to read the ECS chapter now to get all the details related to these systems.

Title: Lesson 11 - Environmental Control
Description: This lesson will walk you through the major components of the Lunar Module Environmental Control System and how to use its checklists.
